awd_titl_txt: Building Social Capital and Professional Efficacy for Computer Science Scholars
awd_abstract_narration:
This "NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics Program (S-STEM)" project at California State University San Marcos (CSUSM), an Hispanic Serving Institution (HSI), will serve the financial, academic, and career needs of a diverse set of talented low income students pursuing a bachelor's degree in an area of acknowledged national need - computer science (CS). The project is designed to break down the barriers faced by low-income students and increase their identity and confidence as CS majors and in the profession.  This population of students to be served typically does not have access to social networks that connect them to academic or professional resources. In line with this, the project is structured to enhance S-STEM Scholars' social capital by providing: professional connections (industry mentors, non-profit organizations), academic connections (faculty mentors), enhanced personal connections (CS peers and other majors), and crucial information (professional development workshops) to increase the likelihood of their academic persistence and professional success in CS fields. Over the 5-year duration of the project, sixty (60) CS students will form four cohorts of CSUSM S-STEM Scholars. Each Scholar will join the project as a sophomore and receive a two year scholarship. The focus of support for sophomore and junior years is based on research that has found middle year undergraduate STEM students struggle with staying engaged and persisting in their major.

The project's goals include: (1) increasing retention rates and academic success for the S-STEM Scholars through evidence-based instructional support and (2) helping the Scholars build social capital and professional efficacy to prepare for a computer science (CS) based internship before graduation. The project team will investigate a key research question: How do social capital, cultural capital and community wealth inform the ways that low-income, academically talented CS majors navigate their middle years? Focusing on the middle years of college will contribute new insights to students' success and add to the growing national and scholarly trend that seeks to understand the 'sophomore slump.' The project will create, implement, and investigate a Fab Friday experience, which consists of students working in teams on Friday afternoons to fabricate computing solutions for real world projects and challenges presented by community and industry partners. The project team will use a mixed methods approach to collect and analyze data. The Fab Friday experiences will provide a venue to connect students with resources from industry and community, which, in turn, will help serve as preparation for the STEM workforce. The project will offer the Scholars a cohort experience that builds on two forms of social capital - bonding (sharing resources and information among the same group) and bridging (gaining information and resources from outside groups, such as faculty and industry partners). The project will serve as a model for other institutions, especially those with a large student body of underrepresented students.

inst.inst_name: California State University San Marcos Corporation
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: CALIFORNIA STATE UNIVERSITY SAN MARCOS CORP

por.por_cntn:
Our project awarded $10,000 scholarships to 68 low-income computer science students at California State University San Marcos (CSUSM) who had demonstrated academic potential. In addition to financial support, the project also provided students with academic coaching, community building activities, and an on-campus co-curricular semester-long project. 

Responding to our institutional data and the national trend of “sophomore slump,” the project focused its financial support during the four semesters of the sophomore and junior years for each scholar. The project leadership worked closely with the Financial Aid and Scholarships Office to establish an application and review process and to obtain institutional data to identify eligible applicants. We promoted the scholarship opportunity through campus-wide flyers and posters, email announcements, postcards sent home during summer break, faculty-led outreach, workshops at identity centers on campus, and classroom visits. Applications were reviewed along with applicants’ transcripts and their responses to short essay prompts. 

Selected scholars were first-generation college students, low income, and primarily students of color. They possessed fewer social networks and understanding of the tech field as compared to students whose parents are college educated and in professions with connections to tech fields. We view our scholars as having significant talent and that they already possessed valuable experiences (e.g., translators for parents, inspired to succeed as role models in their community, resiliency through financial hardships, navigating new social worlds as refugees or immigrants).

The Academic Coach helped scholars identify interest, explore learning styles, design study strategies, and improve organization and time management skills. We also created monthly gatherings to support community building, and workshops on technical and soft skills for workforce readiness. 

Fab Friday was a semester-long, co-curricular activity for our fabulous scholars to work in teams on Friday afternoons to fabricate computing solutions for real world projects. The Fab Friday program was also open to non-scholar students, many of whom share similar backgrounds as the scholars. Overall, more than 200 students participated in the Fab Friday program on over 20 semester-long projects. These projects were challenges presented by campus, community, and industry partners. Fab Friday provided a venue for students to connect with resources from industry and community, which proved to be crucial for their success in securing internships and post-graduation jobs. The close interaction between mentors and students also offered meaningful context for strong letters of recommendation to support students’ applications for internships, post-graduation jobs, and graduate studies. 

The project enhanced the social capital of S-STEM Scholars and helped them overcome the “sophomore slump.” We maintained above 85% retention rates for our scholars, which was more than 20 points above the overall retention rates for the department. Our data collection and analysis of academic coaching experiences found that the students primarily struggled with the following challenges: imposter syndrome, mental health challenges, financial stress, struggles with time management, and – for women – issues related to gender (e.g., isolation in the classroom, microaggressions, familial pressures). Effective academic coaching included helping students develop a growth mindset, seek resources on and off campus, build confidence, and communicate effectively with faculty and family members. 

Fab Friday also made a strong impact on our scholars. Qualitative data from our students indicated the importance of having industry and faculty mentoring and also to gain a deeper understanding of career options. When compared to CS majors surveyed, Fab Friday participants were found to have a statistically significant higher science motivation, career interest, and confidence in their CS abilities. Our research also found that Fab Friday had a positive impact on students of color, women, and women of color. The success of Fab Friday validates that engagement in programs beyond the classroom, fortifying a STEM identity and enhancing professional/career development. 

The success of our project is also built upon the composition of the leadership team: computer science and sociology faculty, the Associate Vice President of Student Affairs, and the academic coach. Having a cross-discipline and cross-campus-unit team that met weekly resulted in creative outreach methods, access to student data for recruitment and on-going academic review, and innovative programming. 

In summary, the project has been impactful for the field of Computer Science Education and Sociology of Education. Our findings indicate that thoughtful interventions that are based on social capital theory and use an asset base approach to student development makes a difference in the experiences of low income, students of color. The field of Computer Science education has a focus on equity and access, and our project is strongly aligned with scholars who research what makes a difference in the retention and post-graduate success of historically underrepresented students. In particular, our analysis indicated that our programming made strides with students of color. The Fab Friday program has strengthened the partnership between CSUSM and the local tech industry by engaging companies to sponsor project-based learning opportunities for CSUSM students.

Modified by: Youwen Ouyang
